primary_factors: Forecast storm-total snowfall around 8.5" concentrated from midday Saturday through early Sunday, not during a school commute window
Temperatures stay below freezing, so accumulation and slick conditions are guaranteed, but roads and lots have all day Sunday for cleanup
Historical patterns for similar early-season weekend storms in Kent County show only about a one-third chance of a Monday snow day, with many districts opening or using only delays
No blizzard-level winds or extreme cold; impacts are significant but within what Rockford/Kent County typically manage without automatic closure
Safety analysis flags significant but not catastrophic travel issues, with worst conditions ending by late Sunday morning and minimal direct impact on a Monday morning commute
decision_rationale:
Using Michigan-specific thresholds: 8.6" of snow and a Winter Storm Watch would normally push probabilities high (60–80%) if the heaviest snow aligned with a school commute. Here, the core of the storm is Saturday daytime through late evening, tapering into early Sunday, with sub-freezing temps but manageable winds (10–20 mph, gusts <30 mph) and no extreme cold. That timing is the key: schools are already closed when travel is worst, and road crews plus building/lot crews can work through Sunday.

Historical analogs in Kent County for weekend-focused 6–9" events show a snow-day rate closer to 25–35%, not the 60%+ seen when heavy snow hits a weekday morning. Rockford also has a higher bar for closing: typical closures combine heavy snow DURING the commute, whiteout/strong drifting, or dangerous wind chills, which are not present here. 

Safety and infrastructure assessments show significant weekend travel impacts and high ice risk, but they explicitly note minimal morning-commute impact and frame Monday as a cleanup/contingency question rather than a likely full closure. Roads may be messy in spots, but primary routes and lots are likely to be serviceable by Monday with standard plowing and salting.

Balancing: (1) strong storm magnitude (pulls probability up), (2) weekend-centric timing and good prep window (pulls down), (3) local tolerance and historical behavior (pulls down), the calibrated outcome is a roughly one-in-three chance that Rockford Public Schools will declare a snow day on the next school day after this storm, with a slightly higher additional chance of a delay. To remain decisive and avoid the 40–60% uncertainty band, the final call is 33%.
